head.title: Society's Ambivalence Clouds Date Rape Issue; 'Beat It, Buster'

hedline.hl1: Society's Ambivalence Clouds Date Rape Issue; 'Beat It, Buster'

block.p: Cheers to Katie Roiphe ("Date Rape Hysteria," Op-Ed, Nov. 20) for daring to question the feminist party line without relinquishing her feminist credentials.
Cheers to Katie Roiphe ("Date Rape Hysteria," Op-Ed, Nov. 20) for daring to question the feminist party line without relinquishing her feminist credentials.

In our paranoia regarding date rape, we wander far afield from the violent act of forced penetration apparently to find an all-inclusive definition for stereotype male behavior. Let's not posture ourselves as delicate, simpering, helpless hoop-skirted innocents who don't know the score. A simple "Beat it, buster" will get the message across in most circumstances -- if that is the message we want delivered. Which doesn't make true date rape any the less repugnant and punishable.
But let's be careful not to dump every sexual encounter into that basket. We have indeed come too far for that. EMILY ROSEN Scarsdale, N.Y., Nov. 20, 1991
